animalOfTheDay.name: wren
facts: They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.
Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.

calendar.name: wren
facts: The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.

randomAnimals.name: serval
facts: Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.
Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.

randomAnimals.name: wild dog
facts: African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

randomAnimals.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.
